title.narrative: Paris21 and SCB partnership- SDG Capacity development
Paris21 and SCB partnership- SDG Capacity development

description.narrative:
Against the background of the Cape Town Global Action Plan (CPGAP), the overall objectives for the development intervention are; - Low and middle income countries have the possibility and capacity to participate in global dialogue and follow up on the 2030 Agenda. - Inclusive partnerships established, including low and middle income countries, that contribute to improving the use of data and statistics in the follow-up and global implementation of the 2030 Agenda.
The specific objective for the development intervention is improved quality, availability and use of data and indicators in following up the implementation of the 2030 Agenda. In order to achieve this specific objective, the partners will work together over the next four years towards the following intermediate outcomes:
- Improved knowledge and capacity among data users and producers (CTGAP 2, 4) - Improved global/regional dialogue and mutual learning across national statistical systems and the data ecosystem for better coordination and increased data use/demand (CTGAP 1, 5 and 6) - Increased capacity at national level to reduce data gaps and produce quality statistics through agile data planning processes (CTGAP 2, 3)

OECD/PARIS21 and Statistic Sweden, a specialist Swedish authority, have applied for funding of approximately SEK 40 000 000 to jointly carry out the “Global program to develop capacity in data and statistics for the 2030 Agenda” during the period 2019-2022.
The overall objectives for the intervention are:
1. Low and middle income countries have the possibility and capacity to participate in global dialogue and follow up on the 2030 Agenda.
2. Inclusive partnership established, including low and middle income countries, that contribute to improving the use of data and statistics in the follow-up and global implementation of the 2030-Agenda.
The specific objective for the development intervention is:
- Improved quality availability and use of data and indicators in following up on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda.
In order to achieve the specific objective, the partners will work together over the next four years towards the following intermediate outcomes:
- Improved knowledge and capacity among data users and producers. - Improved global/regional dialogue and mutual learning across national statistical systems and the data ecosystem for better coordination and increased data use/demand. - Increased capacity at national level to reduce data gaps and produce quality statistics through agile data planning processes.
The intervention is in line with PARIS21 Program of Work, which has a total annual budget of approximately 5 MEURO. The largest donors are DIFID, Switzerland and Canada. The Swedish contribution to OECD/PARIS 21 is approximately 6 MSEK over a four-year period, in total 24 MSEK. In addition, approximately 4 MSEK will annually be provided to Statistics Sweden, in total 16,4 MSEK. The total contribution is 40 400 000 SEK.

OECD/PARIS21 och SCB, en svensk myndighet med omfattade erfarenhet av bilateralt utvecklingsarbete inom statistik, har ansökt om finansiering på 40 miljoner kronor för att i partnerskap genomföra ett "Globalt program för att utveckla kapacitet i data och statistik för Agenda 2030" under perioden 2019-2022.
De övergripande målen för programmet är:
1. Låg- och medelinkomstländer har möjlighet och kapacitet att delta i global dialog och följa upp 2030-agendan.
2. Inkluderande partnerskap, inklusive låg- och medelinkomstländer, som bidrar till att förbättra användningen av data och statistik i uppföljningen och det globala genomförandet av 2030-agendan.
Det specifika målet för programmet är:
- Förbättrad tillgänglighet och användning av data och indikatorer för uppföljning av genomförandet av 2030-agendan.
För att uppnå det specifika målet ska parterna samarbeta mot följande resultat:
- Förbättrad kunskap och kapacitet bland användare av data och dataproducenter. - Förbättrad global/regional dialog och ömsesidigt lärande mellan nationella statistiska system och data-ekosystem för bättre samordning och ökad användning och efterfrågan av data. - Ökad kapacitet på nationell nivå för att minska datagap och producera statistik av hög kvalitet, genom agila dataplaneringsprocesser.
Programmet går i linje med PARIS21:s beslutade arbetsplan. Arbetsplanen har en total årlig budget på cirka 5 MEURO. De största givarna till OECD/PARIS21 är DIFID, Schweiz och Kanada.
Det svenska bidraget till OECD/PARIS21 är årligen cirka 6 MSEK över en fyraårsperiod, totalt 24 MSEK.
Utöver bidraget till OECD/PARIS21 kommer Sida att årligen avsätta cirka 4 MSEK för SCB som ska bidra till PARIS21 med sin specifika kompetens kring administrativa system/data, systematisk produktion av gender data, nationalräkenskaper och specifik kontextkunskap. SCB:s totala budget uppgår till 16,4 MSEK.
Den totala budgeten för denna insats uppgår till 40 400 000 SEK.

tag.narrative: 16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.

17.18 - By 2020, enhance capacity-building support to developing countries, including for least developed countries and small island developing States, to increase significantly the availability of high-quality, timely and reliable data disaggregated by income, gender, age, race, ethnicity, migratory status, disability, geographic location and other characteristics relevant in national contexts

17.18 - By 2020, enhance capacity-building support to developing countries, including for least developed countries and small island developing States, to increase significantly the availability of high-quality, timely and reliable data disaggregated by income, gender, age, race, ethnicity, migratory status, disability, geographic location and other characteristics relevant in national contexts.

17.19 - By 2030, build on existing initiatives to develop measurements of progress on sustainable development that complement gross domestic product, and support statistical capacity-building in developing countries

17.19 - By 2030, build on existing initiatives to develop measurements of progress on sustainable development that complement gross domestic product, and support statistical capacity-building in developing countries.

title.narrative: Beslut om insats PARIS21 och SCB _ SDG Capacity Development

description.narrative:
In 2020 PARIS21 set out to deliver on its 2016-2020 strategy, while transitioning to a new 2021-2025 strategy, this included designing a new, unified results framework. The Programme of work for 2020 followed the four pillar its 2016- 2020 Strategy: Knowledge-Sharing and Innovation Incubator, Advocacy, Co-ordination and Monitoring, and Technical Support.
In the light of the COVID-19 pandemic nations requested timely, high-quality, disaggregated data and statistics in order to design response and recovery policies that are effective and inclusive. During the year PARIS21 reported an increased demand for support from partner countries. PARIS21 adjusted its programme of work for 2020 and Sida decided to increase its support towards the implementation of the adjusted workplan.
A selection of results include: Support to partners in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic; PARIS21s approach to country engagements during the crisis was informed through the work of the PARIS21 COVID-19 Rapid Action Task Force, which produced a policy brief and a strategic operations guide for national statistical offices. Throughout 2020, PARIS21 offered technical support and peer to-peer learning opportunities to partners to help mitigate the impact of COVID-19 on National Statistical Offices (NSOs) and national statistical systems. PARIS21 produced advocacy materials to position statistical capacity development as a priority topic in times of COVID-19.
Gender data; Gender continued to be a key focus for PARIS21 and SCB in 2020 and has been integrated across its Programme of Work: from National Strategy for the Development of Statistics (NSDS). NSDS trainings and support, NSS or data and capacity assessments, the PARIS21 Academy e-learning site has a specific training on gender data.
Innovation in data and statistics by promoting peer learning and custom solutions to National Statistic Offices (NSO) Digital coordination was enabled in several countries, for example in Paraguay where ADPAT was used as a tool for monitoring strategic programs and interventions. On the front of new data sources, PARIS21 piloted a knowledge-sharing project between World Data Lab (WDL) and DANE Colombia on geospatial data and published a working paper on Re-using Citizen-Generated Data for Official Reporting. It also developed a working paper on bridging the data-policy gap in Africa with the Mo Ibrahim Foundation. Five webinars were organised from June to December 2020 (one webinar per month on average) and around 500 participants from different audiences joined the events.
Development of guidelines; revised NSDS Guidelines 3.0, the Capacity Development 4.0 Guidelines, the Data Flow Analysis Framework Guidelines, and a Thematic Guide on Geospatial Data Integration in Official Statistics. Additionally, PARIS21 contributed a chapter on data openness to the PRAIA Group Handbook on Governance Statistics, which represents a major breakthrough for good data on governance.
More and better financing for development data. PARIS21 continued to serve as the Secretariat of the Bern Network on Financing Data for Development, a global alliance with members from aid and development agencies, NSOs, international organisations, private sector partnerships and civil societies dedicated to promoting more and better financing for development data. In 2020, the network actively organised multiple high-level events to advocate for more and better funding for data and began the development of an innovative new platform, the Clearinghouse for Financing Development Data, to enhance transparency, coordination, alignment and effective decision-making for data investments. PARIS21 organised consultations with over twenty partner countries, development agencies, and other stakeholders and ran a global survey to inform the design of the platform. The clearinghouse will be launched in the latter half of 2021.
Trust in data. PARIS21 opened its first ever call for proposals for projects aiming to strengthen trust in data and statistics in low- and middle-income countries under the PARIS21 2020 Trust Initiative, which received over 60 submissions and led to three projects in Senegal, Vanuatu and Uganda receiving micro-grants Delivered on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) data for which the PARIS21 Secretariat is custodian. All three SDGs are prioritised as Tier 1 since 2019:
18.2 Number of countries that have national statistical legislation that complies with the Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics 18.3 Number of countries with a national statistical plan that is fully funded and under implementation, by source of funding 19.1 Dollar value of all resources made available to strengthen statistical capacity in developing countries
Forecasted aid to statistics for the PARIS21s Partner Report on Support to Statistics (PRESS 2020). Financial support to statistics during the COVID-19 pandemic could be followed close to real-time. The PRESS 2020 highlights that under COVID-19, data needs have never been higher yet financing remained stagnant. 63% of low-income and lower-middle income countries were found to be in great need of additional financing for data and statistics due to the challenges posed by the pandemic, among other key findings.
Co-chaired with the Philippines Statistical Authority a global task team on new trends and opportunities in statistical coordination. The task team helps understand and improve the abilities of national statistics offices, other government institutions, representatives from the private sector, civil society organisations and academia to coordinate strategically, communicate across institutions and build strong networks on sub-national, national, sub-regional, regional and international levels.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
